headline: Southern-Style Collard Greens
description: This Southern collard greens recipe is slow-simmered with ham hocks just like mama used to make. A tasty side dish that brings good luck in the New Year.
name: Southern-Style Collard Greens
recipeIngredient: 0.75 teaspoon ground black pepper, or to taste

recipeInstructions.text: Combine onions, ham hocks, and garlic in a stockpot; add chicken broth. Cook mixture over medium heat until meat is falling off the bone, 1 to 2 hours.
Stir collard greens, vinegar, sugar, salt, and pepper into the broth mixture; cook until greens have reached desired tenderness, about 2 more hours.

review.reviewBody: please stop with the beyond mushy greens recipes! 2 hours of cook time on greens is waaay too long and produces overcooked mushy greens. Cook down your hamhocks first for about 2-2.5 hours or so. Then add the greens into the broth and dont overcook them.

In previous comments, I misunderstood the cooks comment about cutting down cooking time when using smoked turkey instead of pork. He was only referring to the cooking time of the turkey, before adding the greens, which is totally correct. Here are a few other comment: The chicken broth is much more bland than the flavor extracted from the smoked meat. You can easily omit the brother...just add a bit extra salt and you will hardly know the difference. About the cooking time...sorry for you Instant Pot (or other pressure cooker) aficionados: You can get the same tenderness, and it will be "OK"...but you will NOT get the same flavor as from cooking "low & slow", if you cook greens fast, under pressure. Only low and slow does it...hence the "crock pot" sort of cooking works well, but "express" cooking methods do not.
